title: A lesson learned at the fair: the proper form for throwing an axe
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
A lesson learned at the fair: the proper form for throwing an axe

 August 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Dorchester Star 
 
 112
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When you think fair, you think games, maybe amusement rides, but the Caroline Dorchester County Fair does some things a bit different.One interesting attraction, which I had the opportunity to participate in while covering the fair Wednesday, was the lumberjack demo.
I met Ray Geist, a Talbot County native and former Timber Sports professional. He showed me the proper way to throw an axe and shared some of his experiences with Timber Sports in the past.
You can read about the experience in the story below.
Also in today's newsletter: women leaders offer advice on mindfulness, federal officials introduce new funding in fight against blue catfish and more.
Thanks for reading.
— Ahmad Garnett

title: Police investigating Easton homicide
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Police investigating Easton homicide

 August 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 123
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Easton Police Department is investigating a Monday evening homicide on Blake Street.Officers were dispatched to the area of 104 Blake St. around 7 p.m.Monday for a report of a person who was shot and lying in the grass.Police rendered aid until Talbot County paramedics arrived.The victim, identified as Ty A. Brooks, 55, of Easton, died from his injuries at the scene. Brooks was transported to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner for an autopsy.Police later learned that Brooks was in an argument with people on the street. After shots were fired, witnesses saw a white SUV flee the scene with Black male occupants, police said.Police said the homicide is an ongoing investigation. Investigators ask anyone with information

title: Chester woman charged in January Bay Bridge crash
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Chester woman charged in January Bay Bridge crash

 August 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 271
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — A Queen Anne's County woman has been charged in the Jan. 27 collision on the Bay Bridge involving more than 20 vehicles. According to court documents, the State filed charges this week against Gwendolyn Persina, age 48 of Chester.Those charges include causing life threatening injuries while operating a vehicle, driving under the influence of alcohol, driving while impaired by a controlled dangerous substance and driving on a suspended license.
The multi-vehicle incident on the westbound span of the bridge had travel shut down for several hours.
Through the course of investigation, the Maryland Department of Transportation Authority Police Collision Reconstruction Unit determined Persina was driving at high speeds and erratically, contributing to the crash.
Queen Anne's County State's Attorney Lance Richardson said he requested the court to hold Persina in the detention center during the Aug. 29 bail review because she was on probation for a DWI at the time of the accident.
In 2022, Persina had been found guilty in Queen Anne's County Circuit Court of driving while impaired by alcohol. Her 18 month probation was still in effect at the time of the January incident.
Richardson said he made the request because he believed Persina is "a threat to public safety with her potential to drive in a dangerous manner again if she were to be released on pre trial supervision."
"The chain reaction collision also ultimately caused an innocent man to lose his arm in the accident," Richardson said.
An arrest warrant was issued for Persina on Aug. 27. During a bail hearing on Aug. 29, Persina was ordered to be held pending trial. A jury trial has been set for February.

title: Hillsboro house fire results in $100K in damages
author: Staff Writer
content:
Hillsboro house fire results in $100K in damages

 May 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 122
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A house fire that broke out in Hillsboro shortly after 8 p.m. Tuesday resulted in $100,000 in damages, according to a release from the Office of the State Fire Marshal.A firefighter was transported to a local medical center after sustaining an injury while combatting the blaze, the fire marshal said.
The occupants of the two-story, wood-framed house, who were home at the time and initially observed smoke and fire coming from the interior first floor bedroom.
The occupants were able to escape the house uninjured with their multiple pet dogs.
It took 60 firefighters approximately one hour to control the fire, according to the fire marshal. The cause of the fire is under investigation.
Anyone with information about the fire is asked to call 410-822-7609.

title: Hummingbird Inn: a bed and breakfast filled with love and community
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Hummingbird Inn: a bed and breakfast filled with love and community

 August 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Business 
 
 769
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Owning a bed an breakfast was not a dream Eric Levinson had on his own. The plan was created alongside his late husband, Kevin Woloshyn.The Hummingbird Inn, located on North Aurora Street in Easton, is a product of their shared love of traveling and hospitality.
The foundation of the inn and their love began many years ago online, when computer monitors had one color and there were no graphics, according to Levinson. Levinson, who at the time was working in Manhattan, New York, in IT management, went on Internet Relay Chat and began talking to Woloshyn, who was from Alberta, Canada. They connected and soon began sending letters to each other and talking on the phone.
Eventually, they made the decision to have Woloshyn move to New York. Same-sex marriage was not legal at the time, and the couple had to find alternatives to be together through work visas, but once they, did they did not want to be apart.
"He was one of these life-of-the-party guys," Levinson said. "He would walk into a room, and everybody was just enamored with him. He was very charismatic, and outgoing, and funny and silly, but extremely intelligent. He spoke seven languages. He and I traveled the world together."
Levinson said Woloshyn was determined to help him find his passion. Bit by bit, Levinson tried to hone in his interest of traveling, cooking and connecting to people. He enrolled in the New York Culinary Institute and began working in a couple of restaurants in Manhattan.
Eventually the idea of opening a bed and breakfast came to the couple, and they decided it would be a project they could do together in the future.
After years of being together Levinson and Woloshyn moved to Canada, where same-sex marriage was legal, and got married. The plan was to wait for same-sex marriage to be legalized before moving back to the U.S., and at the time the issue was being presented to the Supreme Court.
But just before same-sex marriage was legalized, Woloshyn was tragically killed by a drunk driver.
"Ever since Kevin was taken away, I realized that tomorrow is not guaranteed," Levinson said. "You have to live every life to the fullest."
With the help of his sister Brooke Drake and his realtor (and future best friend) Jana Mewedith, Levinson found what is now the Hummingbird Inn.
It has become a popular bed and breakfast where Levinson hosts events such as weddings, dark dinner experiences, annual Pride events, halloween parities, tea events and fundraisers for local nonprofits.
Drake said she is proud of her brother and the success he has found in Easton.
"It was their dream, and he's done a great job to bring that dream to life," Drake said. "We, me and my husband, have just been so happy for him to have him be able to change his life like this and move forward into a wonderful community that's embraced him and made his inn a success."
Levinson is known as an "ambassador of Easton" by many of his guests.
Dan Schumacher, a former guest and current Easton resident, credits Levinson's hospitality for bringing him and his husband to the town.
"Eric and the Hummingbird Inn have been instrumental in attracting new residents to the town of Easton," Schumacher said. "I know a number of couples who visited because the inn allows dogs, can host weddings or because it's LGBTQ friendly (the latter of which attracted my husband Rob and I) … Many of us have purchased homes here and now call Easton our home."
Throughout the inn, hummingbirds can be found in every room, framed on many walls and tiny crystal birds floating on every ceiling. In the entrance, there is a wall of framed cards and art of hummingbirds sent by guests called a "charm" wall, since that is the official name of a group of hummingbirds.
Levinson said that for the vast majority of his life, he had no connection to the bird. But after his husband died, he began receiving many sympathy cards with hummingbirds on them.
For a while, he was confused by all the hummingbird cards. After a bit of research, he learned of the lore associated with the bird.
Hummingbirds are thought to take on the spirit of people who were charismatic and full of life after they had passed, Levinson said.
"I used the hummingbird as a remembrance symbol after he died, and then when the inn started to actually come together, I knew I was going to rename it," Levinson said. "… Knowing this was something that Kevin and I were originally planning to do together, that's why it's called Hummingbird Inn — because it's in his memory."

title: Brutal treatment of beautiful field
content:
Brutal treatment of beautiful field

 August 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A7 | Section: Letters 
 
 165
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I live in the Greens at Cross Court. Across from the entrance to the complex is an open field about the size of a football field.For most of the years that we have lived here that field was left in its natural state. That meant lots of wild flowers (chicory, daisies, black-eyed Susans, Queen Anne's lace, Joe Pye, milkweed, etc.).Also birds were among the inhabitants, especially redwing blackbirds, as well as many butterflies (swallowtails, monarchs, buckeyes, fritillaries, cabbage whites, blues, morning cloaks).Now twice a year it is mowed down to an ugly field of clumps of vegetation.And why? So I can see the bypass.To destroy such a natural magnet for native flowers, butterflies and birds makes a mockery of leadership that professes to care about the environment.My question is: What government agencies make this decision - town, county or state? I want the responsible government entity to be aware of the unhappiness that this brutal treatment of a formerly beautiful field has caused.JAMES CARROLL Easton

title: Educators need to return to basics
author: Staff Writer
content:
Educators need to return to basics

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 381
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I was glad to hear that Gov. Moore had decided to postpone implementing the experimental Blueprint for Maryland in our schools, due to the $2.7 billion deficit accrued by the state of Maryland.The Blueprint has been described as follows:
"It has taken the focus of schools off teaching students the academic and content knowledge they need to be successful adults in our society and made them 'one stop shopping' for services like medical, dental, nutritional, social engineering and mental health. It has promoted the implementation of 'restorative discipline' which has created a generation of students who are out of control and violent since there are no consequences for bad behavior. It has drained our schools of teachers as they flee to other states where working conditions are better even if the salaries are lower. These are just some of the negative impacts." (Easton Gazette, Dec. 20, 2024)
How disappointed was I to read in The Star Democrat (Jan. 15, 2025) that the Talbot Board of Education wishes to implement the Blueprint anyway, especially equity in math, with an $8.6 million increase to the school budget. With nearly 60% of Talbot County students (grades 3-8) showing a lack of proficiency in basic English language skills, while mathematics proficiency for Talbot County students stands at a dismal 17.2%, the last thing we need is for our children to be guinea pigs in yet another social experiment.
What is equity in math? According to Edutopia: "Math teachers can use short activities based on student goals related to equity in order to make classes feel more inclusive and accessible." The key words are "feel" "inclusive" and "accessible."
I was a sixth grader once, a sixth grader who hated math class. We had a strict teacher, of whom most of us were afraid. But we all learned to multiply and divide, in spite of the negative feelings, unlike, it appears, many of today's children who are not even being encouraged to memorize their times tables.
Those negative feelings can give way to feelings of confidence and assurance when a subject has been mastered. I beg our educators to return to basics and stop making our children the latest casualties of yet another half-baked, ill-conceived progressive scheme for remaking society according to the designs of Karl Marx or Saul Alinsky.
MARY-EILEEN RUSSELL
Claiborne

title: CPS staff under investigation in Caroline County
author: Lily Tierney
content:
CPS staff under investigation in Caroline County

 August 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Caroline 
 
 746
 Words 

 Read News Document

 An investigation into the work of Caroline County Child Protective Services is long overdue, county Sheriff Donnie Baker said.The internal investigation into CPS staff was prompted by an incident on July 13, where a social worker never arrived to a home where child abuse and neglect was reported, according to Baker.
He said the agency has been "lacking in their responses," including showing up over an hour after being called or not responding to calls of abuse or neglect until law enforcement has already handled the situation.
"There are some issues that the local Caroline County Department of Social Services needs to work out, and we have been working with them for quite some time to work out," Baker said.
The state Department of Human Services is conducting the internal investigation. Maryland State Police are investigating the report of abuse and neglect.
Baker and Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin met with the secretary of Human Services about a year ago to address long CPS response times.
"We were promised a lot of changes, and unfortunately, those changes have not come to fruition," Baker said.
The Caroline County Department of Social Services, which oversees CPS, did not respond to requests for comment.
Ben Shnider, director of communications for the state Department of Human Services, which oversees the Caroline County department, wrote in an email to the Star Democrat, "The safety and well-being of Maryland's children is our highest priority, and local departments of social services respond to every report of alleged child abuse or neglect."
According to Department of Human Services policy, the Caroline County Child Protective Services response times fall within the guidelines for responding to reports for the examples that Baker cited.
The policy calls for:
Answering calls of physical or sexual abuse within 24 hours.Answering calls for reports of neglect within five calendar days.Answering calls for cases of substance-exposed newborns within 48 hours.
But Baker and Franklin said this policy leaves law enforcement to act as a middle man, but addressing the problem is complicated.
The Caroline County Department of Social Services is a state-run agency over which the county has no control, making it difficult for local agencies and officials to affect change, Franklin said.
"I have no power to enforce changes, I can only make recommendations," Franklin said.
Baker and Franklin said there have been unfulfilled promises of solutions since the problems began during the pandemic but were vague as to what those problems and promises were, saying they wanted to preserve their working relationships with CPS.
Both said they want a better working relationship with Child Protective Services. State law mandates law enforcement agencies working with CPS.
After-hours reports of child neglect or abuse can be handled in a few different ways. In cases involving high or even moderate risks, a Child Protective Services case worker should be automatically dispatched, but if they cannot respond, law enforcement, generally the sheriff's office, will be sent.
Because of the mandated joint investigations, Baker said law enforcement officers have been picking up the slack when the case workers do not arrive, leading to increased frustration by the officers on the scene.
Part of the problem may be vacancies in the state Department of Human Services, where there is a 7% vacancy rate, although Baker said he thinks the root cause stems from procedural and cultural issues that start with upper management.
"I would say that everything starts from upper management and works its way down as far as a cultural issue," he said. "And I think that there are some procedural issues within the agency itself."
Baker spent a majority of his career working in child abuse investigations and said they are near and dear to his heart.
"I know how hard that is, so it's very disheartening to me when we do not have good partners," Baker said.
Shnider, the Department of Human Services communications director, said his agency "is committed to holding ourselves accountable." His email statement said the department will address any systemic issues that are identified through the investigation.
"Any failure to respond to a report of abuse or neglect in a timely manner is unacceptable," Shnider said. "When mistakes are made, we hold ourselves accountable and take action to ensure we do better moving forward."
In the meantime, Baker and Franklin hope the investigation will bring systemic change that will enhance their partnerships and the safety of the children in Caroline County.
"I hope that some accountability and changes will come to better protect the kids," Franklin said.
This report has been updated to clarify that MSP and DHS are conducting separate investigations.

title: 'Make Rural America Healthy Again': health program seeks feedback
author: Lily Tierney
content:
'Make Rural America Healthy Again': health program seeks feedback

 September 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Headlines 
 
 219
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The One Big Beautiful Bill Act, which was signed into law in June, created the Rural Health Transformation Program, also known as "Make Rural America Healthy Again."The state is currently seeking feedback from residents, particularly rural Marylanders and those who serve them. In addition, local health departments will host listening sessions to understand community needs and solicit ideas and recommendations. Feedback on the program will close on Sept. 30.
The program will provide $50 billion to 50 states over the course of five years. Maryland is projected to see $100 million of those funds. However, the state still needs to apply for the program in order to receive the money.
Half of those funds will be distributed based on rurality, quality of the application and state policy, while the other half will be distributed equally among all states upon approved applications, according to Maryland Department of Health's website. Once applications are approved, funds will be distributed from 2026 to 2030.
The strategic goals of the program are prevention and management of chronic disease, behavioral health, sustainable access, workforce development, innovative care and tech innovation.
The dates of the listening sessions can be found at health.maryland.gov, and questions regarding the process or feedback on the program can be sent to mdh.transformruralhealth@maryland.gov. There is also an option to mail in responses on the website.

title: On 80th anniversary of D-Day, Post members pay homage
author: WILL BONTRAGER
content:
On 80th anniversary of D-Day, Post members pay homage

 June 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER | Section: Local News 
 
 260
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Storm clouds gave way to piercing sunlight on Thursday, June 6, marking the 80th anniversary of D-Day at the John H. Newnam Armory at 509 S. Cross St., Chestertown.Members of the Frank M. Jarman American Legion Post 36 came to pay homage to those soldiers lost on the beaches of Normandy that bleak day in 1944.
Of the 2,501 US troops who died, many were from here.
At the foot of the stone monument, post members laid a wreath and flowers donated by The Mill of Kingstown, showing the Legion is just as active in the community as when they had their building at 9155 American Legion Road.
The monument reads: "In grateful tribute to the men of the medical detachment of the 115th Infantry Regiment Maryland National Guard, both living and dead this shrine is dedicated. Their valiant efforts helped preserve freedom in America, 1941-1945."
At that sacred spot, incoming Post Commander Tim Lloyd, a veteran of the Navy, provided remarks.
"We lost some good people, and their sacrifice gave us our freedom today."
Commander Paul Showalter talked about the clandestine nature of the mission the Kent County soldiers trained for at the Armory.
"Two days prior to June 6, 1944, the activity to get prepared to go to Normandy wasn't mentioned in (President) Roosevelt's fireside chats," he said.
Roosevelt only hinted at it.
In the armory, built in 1931, was where those soldiers trained. From that training area, men went to the European theater and engaged in the largest amphibious invasion in military history, a battle that changed the trajectory of World War II.

title: Program Open Space threatened
author: Staff Writer
content:
Program Open Space threatened

 March 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 285
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Program Open Space was created in 1969 and was funded through of a transfer tax of 0.5 percent on every real estate transaction in the state. This new special tax was designed to directly tie development to available funding for open space and recreational facilities for the public good. Now because of the state budget deficit the Program Open Space funds are being threatened with total removal for the next four years.Program Open Space supports parks, forests and wildlife management areas and is an important contributor to the state's conservation commitments and goals. It also supports community playgrounds, ball fields, tennis courts, hiking trails, historic sites, Chesapeake Bay water access and multiple other community benefits. These programs are important for citizens' wellbeing and also have substantial economic benefit. Quality of life is a very important factor in home and business investment in a community.
I am impressed with the value of open spaces when I visit the Oxford Conservation Park and see the park being enjoyed by people of all ages and abilities. I see toddlers running around, senior citizens — some proceeding slowly with the help of a cane, dog owners with their enthusiastic pets and many others enjoying the outdoors.
I am particularly mindful of the many citizens who safely walked in the park during the worst days of the pandemic for exercise, tranquility and inspiration. The park also has become a highly valued locale for viewing wildlife with, for example, a large number of bird species identified, including recent sightings of quail.
Program Open Space provides very important benefits to residents of the Eastern Shore. I encourage you to contact our Talbot County representatives ask that they continue funding for Program Open Space.
SARAH RAMSEY
Oxford

 PRESTON - Shirley Leah Bennett of Preston passed away on Sunday, September 17, 2023 at her home surrounded by her loving family. She was 86.She was born on December 20, 1936 near Federalsburg, the daughter of the late J. Milton Brown and Leona Paul Brown.After her education she married William F. Bennett, Jr. and they made their home in Preston.He preceded her in death after 70 years of marriage.She worked at Preston Elementary and Federalsburg Elementary Schools in the cafeteria.Many former students always remembered her kindness and her smile. She also assisted her husband with the farming operations for many years.In her free time, Shirley loved crocheting, cooking for her family, working in her flower beds, and spending time with her beloved family and grandchildren.She also enjoyed watching her hummingbirds and listening to Christmas music.She is survived by five children: Brenda Mc-Cann (Ron), Frankie Bennett (Pam), Deborah Bennett of Federalsburg, Tracy Lowe (Gary) of Greenwood and Keith Bennett (Amber) of Lewes; 13 grandchildren, 24 great grandchildren, and 3 great-great grandchildren.The family wishes to express their gratitude to the caregivers Shelly and Avias.In addition to her husband and her parents, she is preceded in death by a son, Kevin Bennett and two brothers Jay Brown and Bill Brown.Funeral services will be held on Monday, September 25, 2023 at 11:00 at the Framptom Funeral Home in Federalsburg. The Reverend Marie Coulbourne will officiate. Interment will follow in Junior Order Cemetery in Preston.The family will receive friends on Sunday from 5:00 to 7:00 and again on Monday from 10:00 to 11:00.Expressions of sympathy may be made to Compass Regional Hospice, 160 Coursevall Drive, Centreville, MD 21617 or to the Preston Vol. Fire Company, Post Office Box 44, Preston, MD 21655. content:
Mary Beth Adams

 January 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 6 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 273
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Mary Beth Adams, 77, of Cambridge passed away on Saturday, December 30, 2023 at TidalHealth Peninsula Regional with her daughter holding her hand. She was born in Cambridge on November 4, 1946 and was a daughter of the late Alois Coughlin Matthews and Franklin Matthews.Ms. Adams was raised in Crapo and graduated from South Dorchester High School class of 1964. She received her Bachelor's and Master Degrees from Salisbury State College.
Ms. Adams started teaching third grade and later sixth grade. After the birth of her daughter, she became supervisor of Elementary Language Arts and the local accountability coordinator. Later she became supervisor of Language Arts and Foreign Language. Ms.
Adams was a consultant to incoming teachers for many years after retirement. She was very active for many years at the South Dorchester Folk Museum, attended First Baptist Church when she was able, a supporter of the Kitty City Rescue, loved to travel, and she was a loyal friend and confidant to many.
She is survived by her daughter Alexis Adams and countless loved ones and friends.
Besides her parents, Ms. Adams is preceded in death by her lifelong friend George Adams.
Honorary pallbearers will be Tom Coughlin, Jr., Richard Culver, Brad Ernst, Craig Ellis, and Harold Wongus.
A funeral service will be held on Monday, January 8, 2024 at 11am at Thomas Funeral Home, P.A. in Cambridge with Rev. Randall T. Blackmon officiating. Family will receive friends from 9 to 11. Interment will be private.
In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to Kitty City Rescue, P.O. Box 1259, Cambridge, MD or to the South Dorchester Folk Museum, 1003 Greenway Drive, Cambridge, MD 21613.

title: Federalsburg celebrates voting rights on anniversary of historic election
author: Tom McCall
content:
Federalsburg celebrates voting rights on anniversary of historic election

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: News 
 
 529
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — Sept. 26 marked the first anniversary of the historic election of the first Black Town Council members in Federalsburg. The community gathered over several days to celebrate.Many Black residents of the town and NAACP members marked the occasion by observing Voting Rights Day on Sept. 26, participating in Unity Day activities on Sept. 28, and appreciating the new signage placed at the entrance to the primarily Black residential community of Brooklyn in Federalsburg.
"Federalsburg was hosting. The town was the organizer of the event. It is the first anniversary," Willie G. Woods, president of the NAACP Caroline County Branch, said. "We were there to support what was happening in Federalsburg. They had a cross section of vendors and participants and music and food."
Woods said it is important to stand up and be heard.
"You have to come together and share your ideas, your viewpoints and your respective cultures. And you have to respect the contributions that the diverse population is making," she said.
Brandy James, a Federalsburg Town Council member elected in last year's historic election, said the event was a success and that there was a good crowd.
"It symbolized unity to me. We had people from every aspect of Federalsburg. The faith-based community was there. Law enforcement was there. Not just Federalsburg police, but also the Caroline County Sheriff was there," said James.
She said there were many vendors there, including the Caroline County Health Department and smoking cessation resources.
"The NAACP has a table, Men For Change, there were churches with tables out there. They were giving away free cotton candy, and the kids had a blast. It was a great way to see everyone from across the lifespan come together and celebrate the unity of Federalsburg," James said.
She said the actual business of sitting on the council is slower than she would like, but she said everyone is being fairly heard.
"I am hopeful to see more African American people run for office in the future, and I am hopeful that the town business will get a little more streamlined and more organized," she said.
The Sept. 26 celebration and plaque were requirements of a settlement in a 2023 lawsuit brought against the town in federal court under the Voting Rights Act of 1965. Through months of charter amendments, legislation and federal court rulings, the town's previous at-large election system was changed in June to a two-district system to ensure more representation of Federalsburg's Black residents. District 1 has a 64% Black population and District 2 is predominantly white.
The sign that was placed at Brooklyn said, in part, "In coordination with the Mayor and the Council of Federalsburg, created an opportunity for Federalsburg's Black community to elect two representatives to the Federalsburg Town Council. Through their efforts, with support of the ACLU of Maryland and the guidance from the United States District Court, the town adopted and implemented a new and fair election system, undoing the 200 year exclusion of Black residents from town government. Federalsburg's historic election on September 26, 2023 resulted in two Black women winning seats to the town council: Darlene Pitt Hammond and Brandy James. This day forever marks a turning point in Federalsburg's diverse community."

content:
St. Michaels approves three new police vehicles

 April 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 247
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — The St. Michaels commissioners plan to invest $215,000 from this fiscal year and next fiscal year into three new police vehicles for the St. Michaels Police Department."These guys are always in need for updated equipment," Alfred Mercier, commissioners president, said.
The company that St. Michaels is buying the police vehicles through will allow the commissioners to pay for one vehicle with this year's fbudget and two in next year's budget. The town will receive all three vehicles up front.
"These are all coming out of speed camera funds that are held in a separate account, so unless there's going to be changes in the FY26 budget, this should be something that we can accomplish," Don Richardson, town manager, said.
While the budget for the vehicles is $215,000, the three vehicles will cost $146,820. The rest will be used for graphics, lights and equipment.
Jeffery Oswald, St. Michaels chief of police, credits the St. Michaels commissioners for their help getting the new vehicles.
"I would have to thank to the commissioners because they're always have the support on keeping our equipment up-to-date to match other agencies surrounding us," Oswald said. "We want to keep our emergency vehicles safe and well equipped so we can provide public safety to the town.
"Our fleet is aging, so having the cost and the liabilities of an aging fleet, so not only it will save us money on maintenance, it will provide a better look to attract officers with new equipment and new vehicles."

title: UD to pay $700K to settle claims it failed to disclose professor's ties to China
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
UD to pay $700K to settle claims it failed to disclose professor's ties to China

 December 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 394
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The University of Delaware has agreed to pay more than $700,000 to settle claims that it failed to disclose a professor's ties to China when accepting a grant from NASA.The settlement was announced Monday by the Department of Justice.
"Federal law requires universities, institutions, and researchers to make disclosures, including certain foreign affiliations, when applying for grants so that the granting agencies can assess whether to fund their research and development," U.S. Attorney David C. Weiss said. "My office will hold accountable applicants who undermine the integrity of the federal grant process by knowingly failing to submit complete and truthful applications."
According to the settlement agreement, in 2020, UD accepted a grant from NASA, which is prohibited from using funds to collaborate with China or any Chinese-owned companies. While accepting the grant, UD certified that the money would not be used to collaborate or coordinate with China.
However, the government later learned that one of lead professors associated with the grant, Xiao-Hai Yan, did in fact have ties to China.
Yan is a faculty member at Xiamen University in China, received funding from the National Science Foundation of China and participates in a program established by the Chinese government to recruit individuals with knowledge or access to foreign technology intellectual property, according to the settlement.
The settlement does not constitute an admission of liability by UD, nor does it prevent the government from pursuing criminal charges against any parties involved.
"Along with our law enforcement partners, we will continue to safeguard taxpayer funds that are intended for federal research and development programs," said Adelle K. Harris, a special agent in charge for the NASA inspector general.
Yan has been a UD professor since 1990. He teaches in the School of Marine Science and Policy and serves as director of the Center for Remote Sensing.
According to a glowing profile of Yan on UD's marketing website, he is "internationally known for using satellites in tracking the notorious weathermaker El Niño and in developing new techniques for monitoring global climate change and coastal responses." In 2019, he received the Outstanding Doctoral Graduate Advising and Mentoring Award from UD President Dennis Assanis.
The article also praises Yan for playing "an integral role in the university's efforts to improve and expand the intellectual exchange between UD and Xiamen University" — the Chinese university that UD failed to disclose Yan's involvement with while accepting the NASA grant.

title: Town of Easton works on sidewalk and stoplights
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Town of Easton works on sidewalk and stoplights

 April 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 232
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Easton residents will see lane or road closures on Goldsborough and Harrison streets as the town conducts multiple projects."So the road closures were for the Harrison Street storm drain improvement project," said Greg Mueller, communications specialist for the town.
While the project was for storm drain improvement, more work will be done on streets.
"So every single traffic light in the town of Easton is working on being replaced," Mueller said. "So they have new lights going in that have better detection systems and are able to cycle more properly, and they're also able to recognize pedestrians, and we'll have pedestrian crossings at each of the signalized lights."
The stop light upgrades are not expected to cause major delays in the town.
"We're largely working on the sidewalks," Mueller said. "But there's going to be many big trucks that come in and out sometimes and sometimes excavators, so likely some lane closures but I don't foresee there being in major lane closures."
According to a post on the Town of Easton Facebook page, "This project was thoroughly planned out by our Engineering Department, who are working closely with Public Works to carry out the construction. Thanks to our senior leadership team (Rick Van Emburgh, Town Engineer; Kody Cario, Director of Engineering; Mike Dickerson, Director of Public Works; Dustin Otto, Construction Division Manager) for their collaborative efforts in making this go as smoothly as possible."

title: Touch-a-truck excites as helicopter touches down
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Touch-a-truck excites as helicopter touches down

 October 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 414
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TOLCHESTER — Families gathered at the Kent Ag Center, Tolchester, on Saturday for the fourth annual Touch a Truck/ Ag Fest event.Operators of heavy vehicles, trucks, tractors, bucket machinery and fire engines lend their time to help kids experience what it's like behind the wheel of the rigs.
Children got to sound off airhorns and pretend to drive front-end loaders, thrilled with the experience.
"Children love this stuff," Steve Green said, standing beside his 2008 custom made tanker. As owner of Green's Septic, he and his employee of six years Pete Padley enjoy educating kids on the vehicles each year.
Other than the big trucks, local and state emergency personnel were on site giving demonstrations.
Chief Logan Quinn from the Kent County Office of Emergency Services had lifesaving items on display: cardiac heart equipment, CPR devices and a pediatric response bag.
Chestertown Police Chief Ron Dixon presented some everyday tools they use to assist the public: bolt cutters, pry bars and jumper cables.
"When people see these items, we hope they see we're there for the community," Dixon said.
With a generous crowd scattered throughout the large grounds, it was calm, a good environment to learn, talking to equipment operators.
That calm was momentarily shattered at around 11:30 a.m. when a helicopter from the Maryland State Police was spotted hovering over the grounds. As soon as the chopper touched grass, kids and adults made a beeline to it, excited to get a tour.
"It's an impressive bird," said airline pilot of 25 years John Strigle. As a civilian volunteer he had a wealth of knowledge he shared along with the state police operators.
They answered questions, letting kids sit in the Agusta Westland AW139, creating lots of memories and providing parents with photo opportunities.
Other than vehicles, the various Kent County 4-H clubs manned stations running activities for the public to enjoy. The Kent Fuzzy Tails & Shiny Scales group allowed a chance to pet the rabbits, talk to their owners and participate in a prize-winning activity.
Principal Agent Associate, 4-H Youth Development Kent County, Beth Hill, behind an inventive bike/blender making pumpkin smoothies, said these kinds of events help generate new members.
In addition kids participated in a hay bale toss and Tic Tac Toe with pumpkins, while Matt Jones gave hayrides and various organizations like Rock Hall Dental fielded questions at tables.
Co-organizer Cindy Moore said Touch-a-truck came about to show appreciation to the 4-H clubs who maintained the place year-round.
She thanked everyone for showing up that day.
"We all work together on this," she said.

title: More Retro Rewinds
content:
More Retro Rewinds

 September 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 240
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "The Adventures of Superman" (Heroes & Icons, Sunday, Sept. 10): Before the 1950s series turned a bit more light and comical under different producers (and in color), the first-season episode "Drums of Death" was a good example of how foreboding the stories it presented could be. Jimmy Olsen (Jack Larson) and Perry White's sister (veteran character actress Mabel Albertson) vanish while investigating a voodoo cult in Haiti, sending Perry (John Hamilton) and Clark Kent (George Reeves) on a quest to find them."Freaky Friday" (Freeform, Monday, Sept. 11): Filmed a couple of times previously and again since, this fanciful body-switch comedy has served the Disney studio well, including in this 2003 version. Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan are quite enjoyable as the mother and daughter who magically make the exchange, a therapist and a would-be musician who each get a new and quite deep understanding of the other by walking in their shoes, quite literally. Mark Harmon and Chad Michael Murray also appear."Magnum, p.i." (getTV, Monday, Sept. 11): "Limbo" is an appropriate title for the episode that concluded Season 7 of the series, since it originally was intended to end the entire show but CBS ended up renewing it for one more round. A seriously wounded Magnum (Tom Selleck) is in a coma, and his ghostly self pays visits to his friends to consider the times he's had with each. Elements of the story continued to play out over the first couple of episodes of Season 8.

title: Spirits soar: Holly Flight spruces Tangier Island once again
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Spirits soar: Holly Flight spruces Tangier Island once again

 December 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 305
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Playing the role of Santa helpers with their planes as reindeer, pilots from throughout the region fly boughs of holly and Christmas cheer to the residents of Tangier Island during the annual Holly Run out of the Bay Bridge Airport Dec. 7Tangier Island has no holly trees, so pilots and Chesapeake Sport Pilot School owner and flight instructor Helen Woods join forces to help deliver decorative greens, supplies and Christmas cheer to support the many elderly shut-in residents of the isolated Chesapeake Bay island.
The event was instigated by the late Ed Nabb Sr. of Cambridge, who started the flights carrying holly tree branches to Tangier in 1968. Now it continues through his son Ed Nabb Jr.
As part of the Carlisle Mission Team, Michael Marra collected funds for construction materials for island home repair, including ramps and deck rails for many of the older or disabled residents.
Every summer for the past 10 years, missionaries go to the island for vacation Bible school, outreach and more, according to Marra.
Since the 1600s, generations of families have lived on the island that faces environmental distress, and it is enormously important to try and keep that culture going, he said.
"To let them know they are not forgotten," he said. "We're there to uplift their spirits as well as their houses."
Through a match in donations, over $15,000 was raised with all funds donated by Holly Run participants supporting the work.
A newer member of Chesapeake Sport Pilot, this was pilot Lenora Kandiner's first time participating in the Holly Run. Kandiner last flew to Tangier Island in the 1980s from New Jersey. "You can't be here without hearing about the Holly Run," she said.
"Pilots always want to fly somewhere, so here's a good cause," breakfast elf volunteer Sandy Dewey said.
More information about the Holly Run can be found at tangierhollyrun.com.

title: Lost in the rubble - How how high is the death toll in Gaza? - Biden, U.S don't trust casualty numbers from Palestinian health agency in Hamas-controlled war zone
content:
Lost in the rubble - How how high is the death toll in Gaza? - Biden, U.S don't trust casualty numbers from Palestinian health agency in Hamas-controlled war zone

 October 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1567
 Words 

 Read News Document

 War casualty figures in Gaza - including the number of children killed - frequently cited by international groups and media outlets are being questioned by U.S. officials, including by President Joe Biden, because they are coming from a Palestinian health agency in the Hamas-controlled territory.The dispute comes as Israel Defense Forces step up already intense bombing of Gaza with ground attacks in the Hamas-controlled Palestinian area along the Mediterranean Sea.Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Saturday IDF ground forces have entered the "gates of evil", announcing the next phases of attacks against Hamas inside Gaza, which has a population of more than 2 million people.A sustained ground invasion faces grim realities of urban warfare and a rising death toll. Jordanian Foreign Minister Ayman Safadi said Friday Israel's "ground war" had begun with power and internet outages across Gaza and increased tank and artillery fire."Israel just launched a ground war on Gaza. Outcome will be a humanitarian catastrophe of epic proportions for years to come," Safadi said in a statement on Twitter/X.'THEY'RE NOT RELIABLE'The Palestinian Health Authority is the main information source from the Palestinian side for deaths and injuries during the war between Israel Defense Forces (IDF) and Hamas after the latter's Oct. 7 attacks inside Israel.Israeli officials said those attacks killed more than 1,400 people (including close to 450 children) and Hamas took more than 220 hostages. U.S. officials said 33 American citizens (many with dual Israeli citizenship) died in the attacks and there are also a still an unconfirmed, small number of Americans missing or also held hostage by Hamas The Palestinian Health Authority reported Friday more than 7,300 people have died in Gaza since the IDF started - including more than 2,900 children. Those numbers are going to expected to rise as the war continues, more ground battles ensue and Gaza civilians (close to half of them children) continue to get caught in the crossfires of the Holy Land war.But American and Israeli officials - including Biden - question how accurate the fatality figures are from the health group which is under the auspices of Hamas and its military and governmental control over Gaza."I have no notion that the Palestinians are telling the truth about how many people are killed. I'm sure innocents have been killed, and it's the price of waging a war," Biden said Oct. 25."I think we should be incredibly careful. I think - well, not 'we' - the Israelis should be incredibly careful to be sure that they're focusing on going after the folks that are propagating this war against Israel. And it's against their interest when that doesn't happen," Biden said. "But I have no confidence in the number that the Palestinians are using." John Kirby, the White House's national security spokesman, reiterated Biden's point during a media session Thursday."We absolutely know that the death toll continues to rise in Gaza.Of course, we know that. But what we're saying is that we shouldn't rely on numbers put forth by Hamas and the Ministry of Health," Kirby said.Kirby also pointed to the bombing of the Al Ahli Arab Hospital, which is operated by the Anglican church and Episcopal Archdiocese of Jerusalem, on Oct. 14 which the U.S. and IDF says was ht by an errant Islamic Jihad rocket.Palestinian officials blamed Israel for the Christian hospital blast and reported a disputed much higher fatality figure."Well, do you remember that attack on the hospital? And what did the Gaza Ministry of Health put out?Something like 500? They slapped the number of 500 on it, you know, within the hour of - of that attack. And, of course, they - the same ministry of health said it was an Israeli airstrike, so we know that's not true. And we've now since found out that the numbers aren't that high, either. They never got up to 500," Kirby said."They're just not reliable," he continued.'UNDER THE RUBBLE'In response to the doubts, the Gazabased health ministry released names, genders and ages of residents who have died in the war since Oct. 7.Media outlets as well as international groups frequently cite the health ministry numbers with some defending their accuracy. They also argue the worsening humanitarian situation in Gaza should not get lost in other disputes.The United National Relief and Works Agency cites the Palestinian health agency numbers and said there are more than 1,500 people in Gaza missing "under the rubble of destroyed buildings - including 870 children." Save the Children International, Amnesty International and other relief groups also cite health ministry numbers as they worry about the situation in Gaza, including the spread of diseases.Defense for Children, a Palestinian group, said the number of deaths in Gaza reported by the healthy ministry, could be lower than the reality of the ground saying there are missing persons "under the rubble" of the war and who have not been confirmed as dead or alive.DOC also blames the U.S. for the deaths."Israeli forces are actively committing the crime of genocide against Palestinian people in the Gaza Strip," said Brad Parker, attorney and senior policy adviser at DCIP. "The United States is not simply standing by, but is actively enabling and supporting the gravest crime under international law making the United States complicit. Israeli warplanes are entirely U.S. sourced and the munitions killing Palestinians in the Gaza Strip are overwhelmingly American-made weapons." The U.S. backs Israel in the war and has moved two aircraft carrier groups, additional get squadrons and 2,900 troops - including a Marine rapid response force to the region. Biden wants Congress to approve $14 billion in military aid for Israel as part of a larger $106 billion war package that includes money for Ukraine in it war with Russia. The U.S. already sends Israel $3.3 billion annually in military aid along with significant outlays to Egypt and Jordan, who refuse to take Gaza refugees.The DOC group said the humanitarian situation in Gaza is dire with lack of potable drinking water and more than 8,000 new COVID cases among Palestinian residents. "Many people have resorted to drinking salt water from agricultural wells," the Palestinian group said.Oxfam International worries about the spread of cholera and other diseases with water treatment and sewage shutdown because of the war. Relief and groups say the situation in Gaza which has a population of more than 2.2 million (close to half of which are children) is dire."The situation for civilians is already intolerable. Our staff are telling us that in some cases, there are up to 70 people crammed into a single room." Amitabh Behar, Oxfam International's executive director.'SLEEPING WITHIN'On Friday, Oct. 27, Pope Francis, Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby, Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem Pierbattista Pizzabella and other Christian leaders held a day of prayer calling for peace and the end violence and war in the Holy Land.The World Council of Churches and Patriarchs and Heads of Churches in Jerusalem are also calling for de-escalations of the war and the protection of churches and other places of refugees in Gaza. There are between 1,000 and 1,300 Christians in the heavily Muslim Palestinian territory. Another 50,000 Christians live in the West Bank and Jerusalem, according to the U.S. State Department.The push comes after Orthodox church leaders and the WCC say an IDF airstrike aimed at nearby Hamas installation struck the compound of the St. Porphyrius Church Oct. 19, which was built in the 5th century and is one of the oldest churches in the world."These blasts led to the sudden and catastrophic collapse of two church halls around the scores of refugees, including women and children, sleeping within," according to a statement by the Patriarchs and Heads of Churches in Jerusalem. "Dozens found themselves instantly crushed beneath the rubble." Eighteen people have died, including nine children, according to WCC.The Holy Land Christian churches have also called for more humanitarian aid be allowed into Gaza, for all sides to stop targeting civilians and for a ceasefire.HAMAS' FAULTThe IDF says misfired rockets from Hamas and other Islamic militants are resulting in deaths and injuries in Gaza, including the Anglican hospital blast, and that Hamas has stolen or hoarded fuel that could be use by hospitals and to operate water treatment plants and sewage pumping stations."Hamas is determining the level of the humanitarian crisis by not handing over that fuel to the United Nations," an IDF spokesman said Oct. 25.The day before, the IDF posted images of fuel storage facilities operated by Hamas in response to UNRWA pushes for fuel shipments into Gaza during the wartime siege."These fuel tanks are inside Gaza," IDF said pointing to reconnaissance photos and responding to the UN group's bid to get fuel included in relief shipments. "They contain more than 500,000 liters of fuel.Ask Hamas if you can have some." The Israelis also posted social media graphics and information contending Hamas has underground facilities beneath the Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza. Hamas continues to hold more than 220 Israelis (as well as some Americans with dual Israeli citizenship) in Gaza as leverage as the war and IDF bombardments rage and intensify. 
 
 Caption: ABED KHALED/ASSOCIATED PRESS
 
A wounded Palestinian woman runs following Israeli airstrikes that targeted her neighbourhood in Gaza City, Monday, Oct. 23, 2023.
 
NASSER NASSER/ASSOCIATED PRESS
 
Palestinian protesters hold posters and chant anti Israel slogans during a demonstration in solidarity with the Gaza Strip, in the West Bank city of Ramallah, Friday, Oct. 27, 2023.

title: Eastern Shore legislators discuss education funding and county burdens
author: Konner Metz
content:
Eastern Shore legislators discuss education funding and county burdens

 February 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 398
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Speaking to Eastern Shore legislators Friday, the Department of Legislative Services outlined how local governments may assume costs passed down from the state as Gov. Wes Moore and the state legislature aim to tackle a $3 billion deficit.Hiram Burch, the local government research and analysis manager for the department, shared that local governments across the state will have to pick up around $144 million of the gaps in the fiscal year 2026 budget as proposed.
In Caroline and Talbot counties, projected local cost shifts are in the $700,000 range. Dorchester County is at $830,000, while Queen Anne's County leads the pack for the Mid-Shore at $970,000. Kent is the lowest of the five counties with a $300,000 projection.
Many of those cost shifts come in the education realm, including teacher retirement funding.
Del. Steven Arentz (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) questioned whether record education funding that the governor's office has touted was due to the governor's actions or the result of The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's funding plan for education passed under former Gov. Larry Hogan.
"The governor's saying we have record funding to education," Arentz said. "And I'm wondering if that's mandated from The Blueprint."
"Most education funding is formula-based," Burch said. "He's required to put that in."
Burch said while Moore did provide some "enhanced funding," most of the state aid is required by formulas in The Blueprint.
Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico) said she's hearing from constituents that they're concerned about special education funding amid around $200 million in proposed cuts to the state Developmental Disabilities Administration.
Burch said that none of the state aid reductions will affect special education.
"There were reductions in collaborative learning that impacted the foundation program, the compensatory aid program (and) the English language learners program, but this reduction did not affect special education funding," Burch said.
"That is the one area that has been held harmless by his proposed reductions and postponing the implementation of The Blueprint," he added.
At the close of Friday's budgetary discussions, Del. Chris Adams (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said the state is "very willing to pass unfunded mandates down to the counties."
"What this means really for Eastern Shore citizens, is their tax rates, their rates on their property, are going up," Adams said, referencing increasing property assessments. And that's how we're unfortunately going to be funding Maryland."
"That's my raw take on it, and many of our members are very concerned," Adams said.

title: Realtors work to protect themselves on job
content:
Realtors work to protect themselves on job

 September 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A15 | Section: News 
 
 584
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Smoke detectors and locking doors are obvious safety techniques for homeowners, but there is so much more to keeping homeowners and Realtors safe during the buying and selling process.Real estate leads come in many ways, and a referral from a friend or family member is different than a walk-in or website referral. Realtors are in a unique position that sometimes puts them in harms way.As a buyer or seller being aware of this will make all involved have a better understanding of why Realtors ask or do certain things.Local Realtors say they feel the most vulnerable at open houses and when showing property. Nationally, 4% of agents reported being victims of assault, robbery, theft and other undisclosed crimes.Many of the incidents occurred at open houses, home showings and in the agent's own vehicle.Although locally this is rare, it is still a possibility. Each September, Realtors are reminded about potential risks on the job and are asked to review the Member Safety Report (NAR.Realtor/Safety) for themselves and their clients.Allowing strangers to enter your homes always comes with risks, noted Megan Rosendale, president of Mid-Shore Board of Realtors. That is why jewelry, valuables, and medicines, should be locked up or removed from the property.Some agents make use of visual recordings and posted signs that say "camera in use" to try to deter thieves. There was a situation a few years ago in Talbot County where a person was going to multiple open houses and taking prescriptions, the police and other agents were notified.Realtors also use a lock box system called SentriLock.SentiLock records the code of the agent who opened the box plus the time the box was opened and when the key was returned. A combination box does not have this protection, and once the combination code is given out there is no way to know who is entering your property.Rosendale said, "I also speak with my clients about not showing their home by themselves, not all agents, and buyers are who they say they are. We tell our children not to talk to strangers.I tell my sellers not to talk to other agents or buyers and have them refer all inquiries to me." Here are a few ways some Realtors protect themselves and their clients:▪ They take a picture of the license plate of the buyer's car and the client's identification.▪ They do not drive or ride with their clients unless they know them well.▪ They hold the first meeting with the clients in the real estate office or a public location.▪ They do not hold an open house alone.▪ They never meet a client for the first time at a vacant property.▪ They use a smart phone or application to track their whereabouts and to alert colleagues in case of▪ emergency.▪ They have their phone charged, carry a charging cord and hotspot for poor cell phone areas.▪ They carry mace and maybe even a weapon.We understand that meeting clients in private locations can be a part of our job, as well as hosting open houses and showing vacant properties in areas with poor or no phone coverage, noted Rosendale.That is why it is important to take preventative measures and be aware of the surroundings to help the agents and clients stay safe from would-be criminals.The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors mission is to advocate for its members and the public to preserve the right to own, transfer and utilize real property. For more news and information check out the website midshoreboardofrealtors.com.

title: Demolition of remaining Key Bridge structures beginning around July 7
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@chespub.com
content:
Demolition of remaining Key Bridge structures beginning around July 7

 June 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 457
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Demolition of the remaining Key Bridge structures will begin on or about July 7, the Maryland Transportation Authority announced on June 26.The work is expected to take several months to complete and will involve the use of heavy machinery to dismantle what is left of the bridge.
The process will begin with the removal of the bridge deck over the river, followed by demolition of sections over Hawkins Point and then Sollers Point, the Maryland Transportation Authority said in a release.
This phase of work focuses on removing portions of the existing structure that interfere with the alignment of the new bridge.
No controlled detonations will occur.
The general demolition sequence will include the removal of deck, barriers and parapets over the river from both Hawkins Point and Sollers Point, followed by the removal of deck, barriers, parapets, girders and piers on the landside approaches, down to just below ground level.
Finally, the original north and south abutments will be removed.
Nearby communities should expect to see active tug and barge operations on the river, with heavy equipment and trucks visible on the existing bridge structure.
Barges will serve as protective shielding during demolition and must be avoided by waterway users. Machinery used may include excavators, concrete saws, vacuums, cranes and trucks.
An on-site concrete crusher will recycle materials for haul roads and staging areas, reducing truck trips and cost.
Typical large construction project noise is expected from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m.
Equipment is being installed in nearby communities to capture baseline noise and vibration data before the start of demolition and upcoming construction activities.
Buoys will mark a safety zone, no entry area around active work areas.
Notices will be issued to designate speed restrictions and safety zones to ensure the safe passage of vessels near the construction area.
The Maryland Transportation Authority said that it will continue to provide updates and advance notice of any work that may affect nearby communities, roads or waterways.
Based on months of field investigations and engineering analysis, the bridge alignment is slightly east or downriver of the original structure, remaining entirely within the Maryland Transportation Authority's existing right-of-way. To proceed with construction, the Maryland Transportation Authority is requesting modifications to permits that have been issued by the Maryland Board of Public Works, Maryland Department of the Environment, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and the U.S. Coast Guard in support of the Key Bridge Rebuild, according to the release.
The permit modification requests will reflect updates to the bridge pier foundation design, pier protection elements, and trestle configuration. They also include a decrease in authorized impacts to tidal waters and some additional impacts to non-tidal wetlands and waterways.
A reevaluation of the project's categorical exclusion will also be submitted to the Federal Highway Administration.
No significant increase in environmental impacts is expected, the release said.

title: CAMERON KEEFE
author: Konner Metz
content:
CAMERON KEEFE

 April 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Cameron Keefe 
 
 433
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Email: cameron.keefe99@yahoo.comAge: 25
Family: Martin Keefe, Lynnette Keefe, Dylan Keefe, Brady Keefe, Holly Keefe
Education: B.S. Interdisciplinary in Computer Science and Natural Science
Occupation: Installation Tech at Ustreamwifi LLC
Previous political experience: None
1. Why are you running for the Ward 4 seat on the Easton Town Council?
I love Easton. One day I hope to have a family here, and I want to ensure Easton stays safe and livable (not just survivable) for future families and its current population. It's also very important for young people to step up and get involved in our civil government and approach things with a new perspective and fresh ideas.
2. What issues will you prioritize if elected?
Four points: Financial transparency and responsibility, public safety and stronger communities, smart growth and local business support, and infrastructure and quality of life.
3. What changes would you make to the town's budget, and what budget items should not be cut?
There is a lot of prospective future growth in Easton. We have to make sure the police are well funded. On top of that, the unnecessary fees for businesses need to be cut back, and the process needs to be streamlined. That's just the tip of the iceberg.
4. While the town has grown, affordable housing remains a challenge for residents. How should the town build more housing, in particular affordable housing?
Affordable housing in not necessarily the answer. I want to take a stand that more starter homes be developed in Easton so young families (and old) can afford to live here.
5. What are your plans for public safety in Easton? What can be improved?
I'm pretty sure I addressed this earlier, but to expound: our police department is at least 5 people understaffed. That should never be the case. Increasing their funding while cutting ridiculous and unnecessary items would be the first item on the agenda (some might say that the town will then have less money to use elsewhere, but that just means they need to be more responsible with how they spend taxpayer dollars).
6. In addition to serving the Town of Easton as a whole, what are your plans to improve your ward specifically?
I want to (above all else) listen to my ward. I want to be easily accessible, open minded to concerns and committed to doing what is right by them. I have been given a back to shoulder burdens, not to turn it on the people I am representing.

title: Jennifer Finnigan
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Jennifer Finnigan

 August 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 10A | Section: News 
 
 346
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Note: This interview took place before the SAG-AFTRA actors' strike.Q: Have you liked being in Nova Scotia making "Moonshine" the past several years?A: The show is very loved there, and we ended up getting a place there, a little lake house. We want to go back every year and let our kids have these ideal summers, running around barefoot in the grass and swimming in the lake. It has a really wholesome feel that really resonates with us, and it's great to spend real time there.Q: How have you enjoyed working with your husband. actor Jonathan Silverman ("Weekend at Bernie's"), on A: He's one of the kindest, most generous people on the planet and if he's going to do something with me (professionally), I want our characters to be completely at odds with each other. Frankly, there's nothing more fun than when you've been in a long-term relationship with someone and you know them inside and out - and you don't fight with them much - to go at it with them on camera. I can't even tell you how cathartic it is.We see each other all the time, and part of a happy relationship is a healthy boundary. Many people have said to us over the years, "Why don't you guys do a show together?" Well, it's because I want us to stay married! One of the reasons The CW wanted this show is that Jonny is such a recognizable American actor, and I think that's a nice advantage.Q: How does that work for you yourself, in terms of being well-known in both the U.S. and your native CanadaftA: I think a lot of Canada doesn't even know I'm Canadian. I think I've done nine series at this point, and I've been on everyone's television for 24 years.Part of my excitement in doing this show initially was to boost my profile in Canada, because I have always been patriotic and proud to be a Canadian, though doing a strictly Canadian show is something I've very rarely done. In the way my character Lidia goes back home (in "Moonshine"), this was going back home for me as well.

title: ArtEast to present mouthwatering gallery show
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
ArtEast to present mouthwatering gallery show

 August 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 324
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Local art group ArtEast, (Artists Roundtable — Eastern Shore) offers an art showcase the community can really sink their teeth into with an opening reception of "Bon Appitit" at the Queen Anne's County Centre for the Arts on Sept. 7 from 5 p.m. to 7 p.m.All are welcome to meet local artists and enjoy refreshments as they marvel at unique, food-themed works of art and explore art's relationship to food.
More than just paintings of bowls of fruit, the showcase gives attendees something to chew over, with over 40 unique pieces from 20 local artists, according to member Wende Woodham.
Participating artists were encouraged to think outside the box with the smorgasbord of food-themed mediums to include cotton candy woven yarn, paintings depicting farm to table foods and artwork created out of eggshells, she said.
Embracing the theme of providing a fulfilling meal for the eyes as well as the stomach, nonperishable goods will be collected during the reception and throughout the show for the Haven Ministries Food Bank.
For over 20 years, ArtEast has been a community group talking shop about art in a casual environment as well as sharing in day trips to artistic venues.
All are welcome. The group meets the last Monday of each month at the Kent Island Library.
Giving back to the community, the group annually raises money to support the local community and provide to critical areas in need. Previous donations have been made to Queen Anne's County Public Schools art classes and supporting Ukraine.
The gallery show will run at the Queen Anne's County Centre for the Arts until Sept. 30, after which unsold pieces will be displayed at the Kent Island Library branch.
Queen Anne's County Centre for the Arts is located at 206 S. Commerce St. in Centreville.
Information about ArtEast can be found by contacting Woodham at 410-604-0557. More information about the QAC Art Center can be found at queenannescountyarts.com. Information about Haven Ministries can be found at haven-ministries.org.

title: Pile Drivers: Family-owned marine construction business battles elements, waters
author: Staff Writer
content:
Pile Drivers: Family-owned marine construction business battles elements, waters

 July 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business 
 
 408
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's hot, hard work, but B & B Pile Driving Company got the job done, recently replacing 53 pilings on a dock in the Sassafras River at Betterton Beach.For as long as he could remember, Robert Bramble II has been doing these kind of jobs in Eastern Shore waters.
It's a family business, sharing the trade with his father and uncle, which requires skill, expertise and courage, since the water's unpredictable, especially working with heavy equipment like excavators or a 3,500 lb. hammer.
Bramble's wife Cristal explained, most of the jobs they do in Kent and Cecil County they do with the excavator on a push barge, connected with forks to a small engine boat, maneuvering through the water.
This is the method employed at Betterton Beach for the Rigby Bluff Condominium Association.
In the midday sun, with a rising heat wave, Bramble's crew replaced the damaged pilings, taking him five days.
Cristal said there were more damaged pilings than previously thought.
Using observations that come from a lifetime of experience, Bramble discovered many cracked pilings. Cristal explained that when you put pilings in, it's half in and half out, so at least 25 feet should be buried.
When they are leaning, most likely they are cracked, she added.
And Bramble pointed out no job is the same since the surface varies. Some surfaces are more sandy, or rocky, or like in parts up the river, there's mud.
Also there's the turbulence of the work. Waves are always pushing and pulling the boat and barge, which can lead to a highly dangerous situation. Workers could go overboard if not careful. The push barge with the excavator could tip, especially during the recreational months when people zoom by with speed boats and no consideration for the intricacy of their work.
When the waves are too rough, they have no choice but to come to a complete stop and wait for waves to subside before going back to work."Our guys get frustrated," Cristal said. "Summertime is not fun."
Dangerous, but in 41 years in the business, Bramble's had no incidents...knock on piling wood.
And they stay busy all year round. After the Betterton job was completed at the end of June they were bound for Cecil County.
Bramble also keeps busy fielding questions from curious bystanders too who often stop and ask questions.
His wife of 26 years understands that fully, knowing the business in and out.
"What they do is pretty amazing," she said.
For a complete list of services they offer, visit www.bbpiledriving.com

title: Trump endorses Hogan Senate bid
author: Staff Writer
content:
Trump endorses Hogan Senate bid

 June 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 354
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Republican former Gov. Larry Hogan, who has been one of former President Donald Trump's fiercest critics in the GOP, received Trump's endorsement in his Maryland Senate bid on Thursday in an interview on Fox News."I'd like to see him win," Trump told the network during a trip to Washington, D.C. "I think he has a good chance to win."
The Maryland race could determine control of the Senate, a point Trump noted in the interview.
"I would like to see him win, and we got to take the majority. We have to straighten out our country, so I'd like to see him win," Trump said.
Hogan, who was a popular governor, is trying to become the first Republican in more than 40 years to win a Senate seat in Maryland, where Democrats outnumber Republicans by a 2-1 ratio statewide.
Late last month, Hogan angered Trump's campaign when he said that the public should "respect the verdict and the legal process" prior to Trump's conviction by a Manhattan jury on 34 felony counts related to hush money payments.
"At this dangerously divided moment in our history, all leaders — regardless of party — must not pour fuel on the fire with more toxic partisanship," Hogan posted on X before the verdict was announced. "We must reaffirm what has made this nation great: the rule of law."
Chris LaCivita, a senior Trump campaign adviser, shot back on X: "You just ended your campaign."
Hogan, who is trying to navigate a difficult path running in a heavily Democratic state, has said he will not be attending the Republican National Convention next month in Milwaukee, July 15-18. Hogan did not attend the party's conventions in 2020 and 2016.
In the past two presidential elections, Hogan said he did not vote for Trump, the party nominee. Hogan said he wrote in the name of his father, former U.S. Rep. Larry Hogan Sr., in 2016 and the late President Ronald Reagan in 2020.
Hogan is running against Democrat Angela Alsobrooks, the chief executive of Prince George's County near the nation's capital. The Senate seat is open due to the retirement of Sen. Ben Cardin, a Democrat.
